newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Engen seeks black partner, more Africa turf.
newsitem.headline: Engen seeks black partner, more Africa turf.

text.p: South African fuel and oils company Engen Ltd said on Monday it was keen to tie-up with a black empowerment company, but had not yet found the right deal.
"We would truly embrace the right deal...we have looked but this is not a business where we print money," said chief executive Rob Angel.

South African competitor Sasol Ltd recently signed a deal with black group Naledi Petroleum Industries to create a multi-million rand black-controlled oil company. Sasol holds a 22.5 percent stake in the new business.

Angel said Engen, through its upstream subsidiary Energy Africa Ltd, was also keen to pursue more opportunities in Africa where the firm is already active in countries including Tanzania, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Zaire and Namibia.
"We would expect down the road to be increasing our activities in a number of other African countries," Angel said.
He said Engen's tie-up last year with Malaysian state-owned fuels company Petronas had greatly improved its prospects on the continent.
"They have opened up real posibilities in a blue sky scenario that we would only have dreamt about in the next 10 years," Angel said.
Petronas last June bought a 30 percent stake in Engen for 1.9 billion rand in the second biggest foreign investment in South Africa to date.
